author: By Cecilia Kang and David McCabe
title: Boom Times for Lawyers as Washington Pursues Big Tech
description: Not since the government sued to break up Microsoft in the late 1990s has there been greater demand for people who know the ins and outs of corporate competition law.
content: WASHINGTON — Lawyers at Kellogg, Hansen, Todd, Figel & Frederick, a top corporate law firm, were abuzz on Monday as they grappled with a federal judge’s rulings about antitrust cases related to their client: Facebook.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac
title: Facebook unveils ‘Bulletin,’ a newsletter subscription service.
description: The recent growth of start-ups like Substack and Revue has renewed interest in newsletters.
content: Facebook debuted a newsletter subscription service on Tuesday, an attempt to court influential writers to its platform as more creators branch out from traditional publications and go independent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: The Antitrust Case Against Facebook Crumbles
description: A federal judge delivered a major blow to those trying to shrink Big Tech.
content: Want the DealBook newsletter delivered directly to your inbox each day? Sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: New York Loves Outdoor Dining. Here’s How to Keep the Romance Alive.
description: The rules of restaurant spaces are up for grabs as the city’s Department of Transportation looks to the future of street and sidewalk seating.
content: Last September, a pair of cabins the color of spaghetti sauce went up in the West Village roadbed outside the Italian American restaurant Don Angie. Along the base of each was a stripe of the same checkerboard linoleum used on the dining room floor. Each had three walls perforated by large windows whose rounded corners echoed the ones in the restaurant’s facade. Through the windows could be seen private dining booths separated by transparent floor-to-ceiling partitions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Occupied With Many Things
description: Alan Arbesfeld takes things literally.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — One thing I’ve learned during my years as a crossword enthusiast is that crosswords are not the only word game in town, or even in this publication. Indeed, we see the outpouring of love for word games like the Spelling Bee and Letter Boxed in our Wordplay comments section. I also recently became familiar with Cryptograms, which are printed in the paper and require Times solvers to decode coded phrases. If you are a lover of word games, there’s more than enough to keep you 61A (“Occupied with many things”) forever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Biden Kicks Off Sales Tour to Salvage Bipartisan Infrastructure Deal
description: An event in rural Wisconsin was meant to show liberals that the agreement was sufficiently ambitious — while assuring moderates that the president remained committed to the deal.
content: President Biden opened a combination road show and apology tour centered on his bipartisan infrastructure deal on Tuesday in La Crosse, Wis., as he sought to reassure Republicans that he was committed to the agreement he struck last week and convince liberal and centrist Democrats that the compromise had not dimmed his economic ambitions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: England Overcomes Germany, and Its Demons
description: Two goals at Wembley delivered a place in the quarterfinals of Euro 2020, and banished, for at least one summer, generations of bitter memories.
content: LONDON — The history, England’s players had said, did not matter. All week, the country has wallowed in nostalgia for disappointments the players do not remember, asked them to atone for sins they did not commit. The pain of 1990 was before their time. Only one or two of their number have even the slightest recollection of the curdling hope and sweet regret of 1996.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘Zola’ Review: Twitter? I Hardly Know Her!
description: A notorious tweetstorm arrives onscreen, starring Taylour Paige and Riley Keough.
content: “Is it as good as the book?” is a question movie critics often hear, whether the book in question is a Harry Potter adventure or something more highbrow. “Is it as good as the tweets?” is a new one, at least for this movie critic, and in the case of “Zola” it opens a surprisingly interesting line of inquiry. Tweets may or may not be literature, but as a storytelling medium Twitter has its own integrity, a rhythm and aesthetic that pose distinctive challenges for film adaptation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: The effectiveness of mRNA vaccines.
content: The mRNA vaccines made by Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna set off a persistent immune reaction that may protect against the coronavirus for years, if not a lifetime, without the need for a booster shot, scientists reported yesterday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Post-Lockdown Paris? Think Youth and Sex.
description: Men’s wear designers emerging from the cocoon of safety signaled their eagerness to return to pleasure and fun.
content: PARIS — Everyone was so hungry for togetherness, after a year of serial lockdowns, that Paris last week seemed on the verge of exploding. Corner bars were packed, both inside and out, and so were the open-air bars on the banks of the Seine, the thump of house music reverberating against mossed stone walls. The ambient sound was of people shedding pent-up fear and anxiety with laughter and dancing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: Liquor Laws Once Targeted Gay Bars. Now, One State Is Apologizing.
description: New Jersey’s attorney general apologized for decades-old state policies that shuttered bars for allowing gay patrons to congregate.
content: One tavern in Newark was shut down for a month in 1939 after a man “made up with rouge, lipstick, mascara and fingernail polish” asked for a drink in a “very effeminate voice,” records show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz
title: What Won’t the Nelk Boys Do?
description: Known for their pranks, parties and crude humor, the YouTubers are used to getting in trouble. But for them, the backlash is the brand.
content: SANTA ANA, Calif. — Many big YouTubers earn money by running advertisements on their videos. Not the Nelk Boys. The creators state often and with pride that they make no income from the platform, despite their regular video uploads, high view counts and millions of loyal subscribers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Frieda Fritzshall, 91, Dies; Survived to Create a Holocaust Museum
description: Sent to Auschwitz as a girl, she settled in Chicago after the war and vowed not to let the world forget the atrocities. The museum, in Skokie, Ill., bears witness.
content: Frieda Fritzshall, who not only survived the Holocaust but established a museum outside Chicago to keep the memory of it alive for future generations so history would not repeat itself, died on June 19 in Deerfield, Ill. She was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: House Passes Bill to Speed Visas for Afghans Imperiled for Aiding U.S.
description: The legislation would scrap a requirement that Afghans applying for Special Immigrant Visas undergo a medical examination in the country, allowing them to do so after entering the United States.
content: WASHINGTON — Rushing to help Afghans who face retribution for working alongside American troops in their home country, the House voted overwhelmingly on Tuesday to speed up the process that would allow them to immigrate to the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Canadiens Are Still Out to Prove They Belong
description: Montreal, the playoff team with the fewest regular-season points, made the Stanley Cup finals behind its defense. But after losing Game 1 to the reigning champions, it must adapt one more time.
content: TAMPA, Fla. — The perfect team for these pandemic times dressed in the visiting locker room at Amalie Arena on Monday night. Just as the N.H.L. postseason started to reclaim a scrap of normalcy, with the Canadian bubbles of last summer replaced by games at home venues — and before frothing crowds, no less — along came the Montreal Canadiens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Samuel Getachew
title: Black Valedictorians and the Toxic Trope of Black Exceptionalism
description: We should focus more on dismantling racism than congratulating the few who thrive despite it.
content: I was in the sixth grade in 2014 when a high school senior named Akintunde Ahmad appeared on “The Ellen Show” and announced that he had committed to attend Yale University. After graduating from Oakland Technical High with a 5.0 grade-point average and receiving acceptances to a number of top universities, he had become a bit of a hometown hero, featured in articles that upheld him as an “inner city” success story.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malia Wollan
title: How to Undress Someone Quickly
description: Don’t start frantically grabbing at someone’s garments; trust is key. Let the person you’re disrobing do some of the work.
content: “Wear kneepads, there’s lots of kneeling involved,” says Lacie Bonanni, 36, who works as a so-called dresser, a theatrical worker who helps actors into and out of their costumes. Bonanni got her start on Broadway 11 years ago on a show called “Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark,” which involved stripping off a multitude of skintight bodysuits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: A 70-Year-Old Bat Girl Lives Out Her 60-Year-Old Dream
description: Rejected by the Yankees at age 10 because she was a girl, Gwen Goldman finally got her major league moment — six decades later.
content: Gwen Goldman has adored the Yankees for her entire life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: House Votes to Purge Confederate Statues From the Capitol
description: The bill would direct congressional officials to remove statues of Confederate leaders from public view in the Capitol, the latest bid to do away with prominent symbols of racism.
content: WASHINGTON — The House voted on Tuesday to remove statues honoring Confederate and other white supremacist leaders from public display at the United States Capitol, renewing an effort to rid the seat of American democracy of symbols of rebellion and racism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dina Gachman
title: ‘False Positive’ and the Horror-Filled Truth About Fertility Treatments
description: The new Hulu movie is the rare Hollywood production that portrays the struggles to conceive as women actually experience them.
content: As millions of women know, fertility treatments can be a nightmare. The painful, sterile procedures, the loss of control over your own body, the never-ending blood tests and experiments and strange medications that take over your refrigerator shelves and your life.
source.name: The New York Times

title: New & Noteworthy, From Trump’s America to a Swedish Thriller
description: A selection of recent titles of interest; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
content: THE CRUELTY IS THE POINT: The Past, Present, and Future of Trump’s America, by Adam Serwer. (One World, $28.) These essays by a staff writer at The Atlantic argue that the Trump years simply manifested America’s deep-rooted and abiding inequality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Igor Levit and Joshua Barone
title: Igor Levit on Frederic Rzewski: ‘The People’s Composer’
description: Rzewski, who died on Saturday, could be a prickly contrarian. But for some young artists, including Levit, he was an essential inspiration.
content: The composer Frederic Rzewski, who died on Saturday at 83, left behind a complicated legacy. He wrote intensely political works but didn’t identify as a political artist. In the hours after his death was announced, some musicians described him on social media as warm and encouraging, others as prickly and sometimes troubling. Yet his stature in the field is immense, with contributions to the piano repertoire like “The People United Will Never Be Defeated!” — a titanic set of variations on Sergio Ortega and Quilapayún’s Chilean resistance song “¡El pueblo unido jamás será vencido!” He also had a widespread influence on a younger generation of performers and composers. Among them is the pianist Igor Levit, who elevated “The People United” to the realm of Bach’s “Goldberg” and Beethoven’s “Diabelli” Variations on a celebrated 2015 recording. In an interview, Levit said, “I cannot overstate the importance of this man in my life,” and he shared memories as thorny as Rzewski himself. These are edited excerpts from the conversation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: A Black Hole Feasted on a Neutron Star. 10 Days Later, It Happened Again.
description: Astronomers had long suspected that collisions between black holes and dead stars occurred, but they had no evidence until a pair of recent detections.
content: In January last year, astronomers definitively observed, for the first time, a black hole swallowing a dead star, like a raven devouring roadkill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Proudfoot
title: Meet the First Woman Officially Drafted by the N.B.A.
description: Lusia Harris led her team to three national championships, scored the first basket in women’s Olympic history and was an official draft pick in 1977.
content: As a child growing up in rural Mississippi, Lusia “Lucy” Harris often stayed up past her bedtime watching her favorite N.B.A. players, dreaming of one day playing on the same courts. Reaching 6 feet 3 inches by the time she was in high school, Harris was often called “long and tall and that’s all” by her classmates — but she knew her height would be an asset on the court. And she wasn’t just tall enough to play the game. She was a rare talent who would go on to be a three-time national college champion and an Olympic silver medalist, making her a national sensation by the time she finished her college career.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Irwin
title: Markets Work, but Untangling Global Supply Chains Takes Time
description: Decisions made early in the pandemic are having lasting effects on the ability of industries to fulfill surging demand.
content: The cure for high prices is high prices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper
title: As the U.S. Pulls Out of Afghanistan, Kabul’s Airport Is a Final Stand
description: With the main allied military air base about to close, negotiations are underway with Turkey about continuing to secure the civilian airport as the Taliban advance across the country.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — For years, Hamid Karzai International Airport has been a main gateway to Afghanistan, an aspirational symbol of civilian life and normalcy amid military bases, warplanes and the scars of decades of fighting in the surrounding countryside.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Apple’s Strategy Bends the World
description: How Apple’s business tactics, partly driven by fear, affect the rest of us.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Hirsch
title: The chief executive of Teneo, an influential advisory firm, steps down.
description: Declan Kelly, who “behaved inappropriately” at a charity event last month, will quit the firm he helped found, effective immediately.
content: Declan Kelly, the chief executive of Teneo, the go-to advisory and communications firm for many of the world’s largest companies, said on Tuesday that he would step down. The firm, which specializes in crisis communications, has been dealing with its own turmoil after reports of Mr. Kelly’s drunken misconduct at a charity event last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Marks
title: With hundreds of thousands facing famine in Tigray, aid groups seek access.
description: Aid workers are concerned about a potential new wave of atrocities as Ethiopian and Eritrean forces withdraw from Tigray.
content: International aid agencies on Tuesday continued to raise concern at the lack of humanitarian access for groups trying to deliver food and supplies to tens of thousands of people already suffering from famine in Ethiopia’s Tigray region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: New York’s Lesson for Democrats
description: Are they willing to listen?
content: The Pew Research Center, which does some of the country’s best polls, classifies all Americans as being in one of nine different political groups. The categories range from “core conservatives” on the right to “solid liberals” on the left, with a mix of more complicated groups in the middle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Serena Williams, in Pain and in Tears, Exits Wimbledon With a Leg Injury
description: Williams started her first-round match against Aliaksandra Sasnovich aggressively, but she slipped on the grass court and later fell after injuring her right hamstring.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — Serena Williams’s 20th Wimbledon ended shortly after it began. She retired 34 minutes into the first set of her first-round match against Aliaksandra Sasnovich on Tuesday night because of a right hamstring injury.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Miami, Delta Variant, Serena Williams: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura, Campbell Robertson and Patricia Mazzei
title: Months before the building’s collapse, a condo official warned that damage had ‘gotten significantly worse’ in recent years.
description: The president of the condominium association wrote to residents in April, explaining why they were being asked to pay for $15 million in construction projects.
content: Less than three months before the collapse of the Champlain Towers South condo in Surfside, Fla., the president of the condominium association warned in a letter that the damage in the building had “gotten significantly worse” since it was highlighted in a 2018 inspection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Time to Get Some Ranked-Choice Voting Results
description: Primary Day may have been one week ago, but many races across the city are still not decided because of ranked-choice voting.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: The House plans a vote to speed visas for Afghans who helped the U.S. government.
description: The vote comes as the United States and other countries prepare to withdraw from Afghanistan.
content: Rushing to help Afghans who face retribution for working alongside American troops in their home country, the House is scheduled to vote on Tuesday to speed up the process that would allow them to immigrate to the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Stanford and Giulia Heyward
title: Miami Beach cancels its July 4 fireworks out of respect for the victims.
description: “It’s respectful; this was a tragedy,” said one resident of Surfside, Fla., where a condo building collapsed.
content: Miami Beach has canceled its Independence Day celebrations on Sunday out of respect for the victims of the collapsed condo building in the neighboring town of Surfside, Fla., and their families.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: The Bidens will visit the site of the Florida building collapse on Thursday.
description: President and Jill Biden will visit Surfside, Fla., a week after a condo building collapsed, and are expected to meet with families of the victims and local officials.
content: President Biden and Jill Biden, the first lady, will travel to Florida on Thursday to tour the site of collapsed Champlain Towers South condo complex and comfort the families of the 149 people listed as missing as the excruciating rescue and recovery effort drags on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Levin and Michael Gold
title: L.A. County recommends everyone, even if vaccinated, wear masks indoors over Delta variant concerns.
description: By contrast, New York City’s mayor said fully vaccinated municipal office employees are no longer required to wear masks or adhere to social-distancing protocol inside their offices.
content: After World Health Organization officials urged fully vaccinated people to continue wearing masks out of concern about the global spread of the Delta variant, New York City and Los Angeles County appear to now be taking slightly diverging approaches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke
title: Black Dance Stories: By the Artists, for the People
description: This online show, which wraps up its present incarnation on Thursday, became a serendipitous gathering place and a Thursday-night ritual.
content: The choreographers Robert Battle and Angie Pittman had just met formally for the first time when they were left to talk one on one, in front of a live (virtual) audience, during a recent episode of the conversation series Black Dance Stories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Some Asia-Pacific countries lock down.
content: Countries across the Asia-Pacific region with slow vaccination campaigns are scrambling to slow the spread of the more infectious Delta variant of the coronavirus by resorting to a new round of restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael E. Mann and Susan Joy Hassol
title: That Heat Dome? Yeah, It’s Climate Change.
description: And there are fewer and fewer places to escape from the hot weather.
content: In the old days, we could escape the summer heat by heading north — to the Adirondacks in the East or to the cool, forested Pacific Northwest in the West.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Egan
title: Do I Always Need to Wash Fruits and Vegetables? Do I Need a Special Soap?
description: A food safety specialist offers tips on helping to keep your food safe.
content: To minimize the risk of food poisoning, you really do need to wash produce before eating it, though no special produce washes are required.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Supreme Court Acts Cautiously in Cases on Transgender Rights and Police
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, June 29, 2021.
content: “The proudest moments of the federal judiciary have been when we affirm the burgeoning values of our bright youth, rather than preserve the prejudices of the past.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: England opens up a narrow quarantine exemption for business travelers.
description: Britain, which requires travelers to quarantine, will allow executives to visit so long as their work supports at least 500 British jobs.
content: The British government introduced a new exemption to its quarantine rules on Tuesday for business travelers “bringing significant economic benefit” to England, but the move is unlikely to quell frustrations that certain travel routes in and out of Britain remain effectively shut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Bullard
title: I Wrote About This Environmental Injustice Decades Ago. It Hasn’t Changed.
description: President Biden’s choice of an appointee for a federal energy panel will test his pledge to protect minority communities from environmental hazards.
content: HOUSTON — A majority of people who live in the Texas coastal communities of Brownsville, Corpus Christi and Port Arthur are brown and Black. These communities are also locations for proposed terminals to load liquefied natural gas on tankers bound for overseas markets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: ‘I miss home’: The war spawned a wave of displacement.
description: Almost 2 million people were forced to become migrants because of the war in Tigray. Tens of thousands went to Sudan, and are hoping that the latest news means they can return home.
content: Since the war in Tigray began in November, almost two million people have been displaced from their homes, moving to towns elsewhere in Ethiopia and across the border into Sudan.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Collapse of Champlain Towers
description: Last week, a 13-story residential building near Miami crumbled, prompting a round-the-clock search for survivors and urgent questions about what happened.
content: A few years ago, engineers sounded alarm bells about Champlain Towers, a 13-story, 130-unit residential building in Surfside, Fla. The building, erected in 1981, had major structural issues and was in need of repairs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vallery Lomas
title: Sweet Tea From a Grandmother’s Kettle to Your Table
description: This intense, yet delicate recipe may just push the limit of how much sugar and lemon juice you use.
content: Sweet tea should not be confused with “sweetened tea.” Though they are both iced teas that have been sweetened with sugar, the two are vastly different.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Bloom
title: An Aspiring Editor Meets a Thorny Dilemma
description: Francine Prose’s new novel, “The Vixen,” ushers readers into the rarefied world of old-world publishing.
content: THE VIXENBy Francine Prose
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: What to Know About the Heat Wave
description: The recent triple-digit temperatures in Oregon, Washington State and Canada were exacerbated by an intense drought.
content: The National Weather Service issued another excessive-heat warning on Tuesday for much of Washington State and Oregon that will remain in effect for the next few days. There are also heat advisories in the Northeast, from Philadelphia to Boston. Here is what you need to know about these heat waves:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: ‘We Are Waiting for You’: An Agonizing Vigil for Surfside Families
description: Many families have no choice but to navigate an ugly and liminal place where mourning can feel both necessary and premature.
content: SURFSIDE, Fla. — All around Magaly Ramsey a chorus of newly familiar strangers were shouting out the names of their loved ones, hoping their voices would penetrate the looming pile of debris. These were the people Ms. Ramsey had spent long days with, waiting for any news of their relatives buried under the fallen building.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean and Ben Ezeamalu
title: Biafra Separatist, After Years on Run, Is Held in Nigeria
description: The circumstances surrounding Nnamdi Kanu’s return to the country he fled are murky. Appearing in court on Tuesday, he said he had fled for his life.
content: DAKAR, Senegal — For years he ran an intense and bombastic campaign against the Nigerian government from his hide-out somewhere in exile.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: It’s Not Too Late for a Fourth of July Travel Deal
description: Squeezed by holiday economics, what’s a last-minute, budget-minded traveler to do? Think like a contrarian: Go where the masses aren’t.
content: More than 47 million Americans are expected to travel over the Independence Day holiday between July 1 and 5, nearly matching prepandemic levels, according to AAA, the automobile owners group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang, Alexandra Stevenson and Lam Yik Fei
title: ‘A Form of Brainwashing’: China Remakes Hong Kong
description: Neighbors are urged to report on one another. Children are taught to look for traitors. Officials are pressed to pledge their loyalty.
content: HONG KONG — With each passing day, the boundary between Hong Kong and the rest of China fades faster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seyward Darby
title: Confronting the Threat of QAnon
description: Mia Bloom and Sophie Moskalenko’s “Pastels and Pedophiles” looks at a dangerous movement that is growing in power.
content: PASTELS AND PEDOPHILES Inside the Mind of QAnonBy Mia Bloom and Sophie Moskalenko
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Marantz Henig
title: The Struggles of Those Who Regain Sight and Hearing
description: In “Coming to Our Senses,” Susan R. Barry looks at people who stopped being blind or deaf and then had to adjust to the world.
content: COMING TO OUR SENSESA Boy Who Learned to See, a Girl Who Learned to Hear, and How We All Discover the WorldBy Susan R. Barry
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: What Should I Do With My Grandfather’s Cringey Canvases?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the nudes that are no longer socially acceptable.
content: I’ve inherited from my mother and uncle a collection of paintings by my grandfather, who died in 1969. He was relatively well known in his home city, and many of his paintings are quite lovely. Unfortunately, the themes of some of his paintings are no longer socially acceptable, particularly the many nudes of Black and Asian women, as well as paintings of minorities that are meant to appear exotic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Bayrakdarian
title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
content: $10.85 MILLION
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: A conversation with our Brazil bureau chief.
content: Brazil recently surpassed 500,000 official Covid deaths, the world’s second-highest total behind the U.S. About 1 in every 400 Brazilians has died from the virus, but many experts believe the true death toll may be higher. The virus situation there is not easing, with an average of nearly 70,000 new cases per day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: The $30 Million Founding Father: How ‘Hamilton’ Got Federal Aid
description: The megahit had five separate productions around the nation, and with each applying for $10 million in pandemic relief to help get back onstage, the tally could reach $50 million.
content: “Hamilton” is the biggest Broadway hit in years, and until the coronavirus pandemic shuttered all of its productions, it was making a lot of money: It has played to full houses since it opened in 2015, and on Broadway it has been seen by 2.6 million people and grossed $650 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Timothy Snyder
title: The War on History Is a War on Democracy
description: A scholar of totalitarianism argues that new laws restricting the discussion of race in American schools have dire precedents in Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Hong Kong bars passenger flights from Britain.
description: Hong Kong cited the spread of the more virulent Delta coronavirus variant in the United Kingdom, which will be reclassified as “extremely high-risk.”
content: Hong Kong will suspend all passenger flights from Britain beginning July 1, the government said on Monday, citing the spread of the more virulent Delta coronavirus variant in the United Kingdom, which will be reclassified as “extremely high-risk.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Greer
title: Dear Kamala Harris: It’s a Trap!
description: Harris is a historic but inexperienced vice president, struggling at times, and she is not being helped by her boss.
content: On Sunday, after Vice President Kamala Harris’s visit to the southern border, the White House felt the need to issue a statement calling her trip a “success.” The statement cited as supporting evidence five tweets by Democratic allies of hers and some neutral media accounts. That’s a relatively modest definition of success, but then again, there were no defensive moments like during the NBC News interview in Guatemala in which she called a border visit a “grand gesture” and noted that she hadn’t visited Europe as vice president, either.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Here are the antitrust arguments against Facebook and why a judge rejected them.
description: A federal judge said the Federal Trade Commission had not made its case that Facebook held a monopoly over social networking. And he said states had waited too long to sue.
content: A federal judge on Monday eviscerated arguments in two antitrust suits against Facebook — one filed by the Federal Trade Commission, and the other by attorneys general from 46 states and the District of Columbia and Guam.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Beyond Tulsa, Overlooked Race Massacres Draw New Focus
description: Efforts to teach the histories are gaining momentum even as some states try to limit how racism is discussed in schools.
content: The Elaine massacre of 1919 is believed to be the deadliest episode of racial violence in Arkansas history. But when the historian Brian Mitchell began researching it a few years ago, he met teachers in the state who didn’t know about it or weren’t sure how to explain it to their students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Robertson
title: Nikole Hannah-Jones’s tenure application will go before the U.N.C. board.
description: A resolution of the dispute between the award-winning journalist and the University of North Carolina’s trustees could come during a closed session Wednesday.
content: The University of North Carolina’s board of trustees is scheduled to hold a special meeting on Wednesday amid intensifying pressure over its failure to approve tenure for Nikole Hannah-Jones, the Pulitzer Prize-winning correspondent for The New York Times Magazine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: California’s Red-Hot Real Estate Market Cools Just a Bit
description: Buyers’ fatigue may have helped stabilize sales figures in May, but brokers expect a renewed frenzy in coming months.
content: It’s a shift of only one or two degrees, but the red-hot housing market in California is finally starting to cool.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Wisconsin G.O.P. Wrestles With Just How Much to Indulge Trump
description: The former president set off infighting among state Republicans by saying they were not working hard enough to challenge the 2020 results, accusing them of covering up “election corruption.”
content: Wisconsin Republicans were already going to great lengths to challenge the 2020 election results. They ordered a monthslong government audit of votes in the state. They made a pilgrimage to Arizona to observe the G.O.P. review of votes there. They hired former police officers to investigate Wisconsin’s election and its results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: Major Trial Against Opioid Suppliers Begins in New York
description: New York’s sweeping lawsuit is the first opioid case in which a jury rather than a judge will decide the outcome.
content: Over the course of nearly four hours of opening statements on Tuesday, attorneys for New York described the opioid industry as one that pushed pills and chased profits while disregarding the human toll of addiction, their initial salvo in the first opioid case in the country where a jury rather than a judge will decide the outcome.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Pacific Northwest Continues to Bake Beneath ‘Heat Dome’
description: A wave of ocean air provided some relief after Portland, Ore., reached 116 degrees on Monday. Temperatures reached the 90s there on Tuesday, forecasters said.
content: The heat dome that settled over the Pacific Northwest over the weekend, shattering records and causing roads to buckle in Portland, Ore., is expected to linger for days, as temperatures reached the 90s by Tuesday afternoon, forecasters said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: The Boss Is Back on Broadway. The Workers Are Coming Back, Too.
description: Broadway took its first steps back with the return of Bruce Springsteen’s show, and no one is happier than Jim Barry, an usher at the St. James Theater for 20 years.
content: Jim Barry, masked and ready, perched at the top of the theater stairs, cupping his hands around the outstretched smartphones so he could more easily make out the seat numbers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Rejects Request to Lift Federal Ban on Evictions
description: The C.D.C. had imposed an eviction moratorium, saying it was needed to address the coronavirus pandemic.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday refused to lift a moratorium on evictions that had been imposed by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in response to the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: Britney Spears and the Last Resort of Mental Health Care
description: When it comes to involuntary treatment, the  line between life-saving and abusive can be thin.
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oscar Lopez
title: International Court Rules in Favor of Trans Rights in Honduras
description: The landmark decision from the Inter-American Court of Human Rights, born out of a brutal murder, could have far-reaching implications for L.G.B.T.Q. rights across Latin America.
content: MEXICO CITY — A regional human rights court in Costa Rica ruled on Monday that the Honduran government was responsible for the 2009 killing of a transgender woman, a landmark decision that could have broad implications for trans rights in one of the world’s deadliest regions for L.G.B.T.Q. people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: N.J. attorney general is appointed director of enforcement at the S.E.C.
description: The new director, Gurbir Grewal, has overseen a number of high-profile securities fraud cases, including a 2015 case involving the hacking of thousands of company news releases so a gang of criminals could engage in insider trading.
content: Gary Gensler is turning to a longtime state and federal prosecutor to lead the enforcement division of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Harrison-Caldwell
title: No More Periods When Texting. Period.
description: To younger people, putting a period at the end of a casually written thought could mean that you’re raring for a fight.
content: You’re out with a few friends after a long day at the (Zoom) office. You’ve been presenting a professional version of yourself for eight hours and are so relieved to speak freely at last, with as much slang and intonation and irony as you like. Then another friend joins your group and sits with perfect posture, contributing humorless and grammatically impeccable sentences to the conversation. Are you at ease? Or is this person kind of rubbing you the wrong way?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir and Simon Marks
title: Tigray leaders say they will take the fight into Eritrea.
description: Feeling victorious, the rebels say they will not be safe until they track down the forces that invaded them. But Tigray faces a host of crises immediately, including famine.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — A day after retaking the capital of the northern Tigray region of Ethiopia, rebel forces have indicated they have little appetite for a truce — threatening to drag out the brutal eight-month-long civil war that has embroiled the Horn of Africa nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Declan Walsh
title: Jubilant Tigray Capital Greets Insurgents After Ethiopian Retreat
description: The capture of the capital, Mekelle, by Tigrayan forces was a major blow to Ethiopia’s leader, eight months into a war that has resulted in widespread famine and one of the world’s worst humanitarian crises.
content: MEKELLE, Ethiopia — A column of triumphant fighters paraded into the city just after dawn on Tuesday, led by a woman in camouflage who brandished a Kalashnikov and the flag of the Tigray region of northern Ethiopia, while people poured onto the streets to welcome them — cheering, weeping with relief and chanting “Victory is ours!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: Training the Next Generation of Indigenous Data Scientists
description: A new workshop explores the right of Indigenous people to govern the collection, ownership and use of their biological and cultural data.
content: When Krystal Tsosie introduces her genomics students to the concept of biocommercialism — the extraction of biological resources from Indigenous communities without benefit — she always uses the same example: the Human Genome Diversity Project.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Ito
title: It’s Not Easy Being Greenspeople
description: Transforming winter into spring or creating faux forests and fanciful estates is all in a day’s work for these behind-the-scenes masters of foliage on movie and TV sets.
content: For two decades, Ginny Walsh has worked as a greensperson on a variety of TV shows and movies, from “Meet the Parents” to, most recently, “The Gilded Age.” Greenspeople like Walsh provide and care for the assorted trees and shrubs and grasses on film sets — hence “greens” — but they’ll also step in and help with other nonvegetative tasks like, say, digging graves (for funeral scenes or mob hits) and trenches (for World War I battle sequences). There are fewer than a dozen full-time greenspeople working in New York, according to Walsh. “It’s one of those jobs where people go, ‘Ohhh, I didn’t even know that that exists,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Biden Faces Intense Cross Currents in Iran Policy
description: The airstrikes the president ordered on Iranian-backed militias show how he has to navigate between using force and pursuing diplomacy to revive the nuclear deal.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s decision to strike Iranian-backed militias in Iraq and Syria early on Monday illustrated the delicate balancing act of his approach to Tehran: He must demonstrate that he is willing to use force to defend American interests, while keeping open a fragile diplomatic line of communication as the two countries try to resuscitate the 2015 deal limiting Iran’s nuclear program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Ellen McIlwaine, Slide Guitarist With a Power Voice, Dies at 75
description: Early in her career she played with Jimi Hendrix. She went on to record several well-regarded albums. But she remained under the radar.
content: In the mid-1960s Ellen McIlwaine spent about a month playing in New York with a fellow guitarist whose musical tastes she shared, an undiscovered talent named Jimi Hendrix. They made an unusual pair — a white woman working on her slide-guitar skills and a Black guy developing his own flamboyant style. It was going pretty well, and she thought about formalizing the partnership.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: With an Early Win, Korda Advances His Father’s ‘Half-Crazy’ Plan
description: Petr Korda has long envisioned greatness for his children, the pro golfers Nelly and Jessica and the tennis pro Sebastian, who won his first-round match at Wimbledon.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — Sebastian Korda watched from his father’s hotel room in London on Sunday night as his sister Nelly achieved a major dream, winning the Women’s P.G.A. Championship in Atlanta. Two days later, on a different sort of green, Sebastian kept the family business booming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: As Infrastructure Deal Gathers Steam, Democratic Cracks Begin to Show
description: House progressives say they can bring down the bipartisan bill if they do not get their priorities too, but as White House lobbying steps up, other Democrats have different ideas.
content: WASHINGTON — Liberal House Democrats, squeezed between President Biden’s personal lobbying for a bipartisan infrastructure deal and their own ambitions for a far more expansive domestic agenda, are warning that they will not hesitate to bring down the accord without action on their long-sought priorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: The Maddening Critical Race Theory Debate
description: Liberals should be anti-anti-C.R.T.
content: Christopher Rufo, a clever propagandist who has done more than anyone else to whip up the national uproar over critical race theory, tweeted out in March an explanation of how he was redefining the term.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘She Adored Having a Gay Son’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: Over time, my husband taught himself how to repair every part of our 1919 Foursquare Oregon home. The kitchen was last in our prolonged renovation. When my husband, a recreational property developer, saw his business evaporate in 2008, he finally had time to finish the kitchen. Daily, I’d return from work and see his progress in walls, cabinets, wiring. One day, I returned to discover that he had lowered our kitchen window and cabinets to better suit my 4-foot-10 body. Finally a full view of the park next door — and proof that love can sometimes be measured with a ruler. — Joan Kapowich
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: Why Can’t Americans Go to Canada?
description: Many travelers are wondering why they still can’t visit their neighbor to the north. Here’s why the border remains closed.
content: Americans can now vacation in France, where the one-dose vaccination rate is 49 percent, according to the nonprofit Our World in Data; they can also go to Spain, where the rate is 51 percent, and Greece, 45 percent. But, with very limited exceptions, they still cannot travel to Canada, which, according to one source — the University of Oxford — is leading all countries globally in single-dose vaccination rates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: ‘It’s Tough to Get Out’: How Caribbean Medical Schools Fail Their Students
description: The institutions are expensive, often operated for profit and eager to accept applicants. But graduates have trouble landing residencies and jobs.
content: Last summer, when Dr. Sneha Sheth went online to begin filling out applications for residency — the next stage of her training after medical school — she was hit with a jolt of disappointment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Is There Such a Thing as Too Much Shohei Ohtani?
description: The two-way star for the Los Angeles Angels is defying all doubters. As his innings count rises, the fretting will surely begin.
content: It is remarkable enough that Shohei Ohtani is the first frontline starting pitcher in generations to do double duty as an everyday player. But he is not merely filling both roles for the Los Angeles Angels, he is excelling at them. His numbers put him among the best hitters in the game and have been very solid on the pitching side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Summer Reading Contest Winner Week 1: On ‘Lilith, Lilibet … Lucifer? How Baby Names Went to “L”’
description: Thank you to the teenagers who participated this week, and congratulations to our winner, Sanai, as well as our many runners-up and honorable mentions
content: We received 528 entries from students from around the world for the first week of our 10-week Summer Reading Contest. Thank you to everyone who participated, and congratulations to our winner, Sanai, as well as the 11 runners-up and 15 honorable mentions we honor below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin, Abdi Latif Dahir, Aina J. Khan and Dan Levin
title: W.H.O. officials, concerned about the Delta variant, urge vaccinated people to keep wearing masks.
description: Los Angeles County strongly recommended on Monday that everyone wear masks indoors as a precaution against the Delta variant.
content: World Health Organization officials, concerned about the Delta variant, have urged even fully vaccinated people to continue wearing masks and taking other precautions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Inside Our Subway Tuna Sandwich Test
description: Sending samples to a lab was just the beginning. The reporter behind the recent investigation talks about getting deep into the science of seafood.
content: It started in January, when Choire Sicha, then The New York Times’s Styles editor, posed a question to his team on an internal messaging platform that went something like this:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: OPEC and Allies Hold the Cards as Prices and Demand Rise
description: In the short run, trends in the oil market may be favoring large producers like Saudi Arabia and Russia.
content: The pandemic has worked out far better for the group of oil producers known as OPEC Plus than might have been expected a year ago. After a self-destructive price war, and a brief episode when some oil prices fell below zero, Saudi Arabia, Russia and their allies have emerged in a position that may be stronger than when the lockdowns began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Steinberger
title: A Few Tennis Pros Make a Fortune. Most Barely Scrape By.
description: The superstars of pro tennis get paid staggeringly more than everyone else. Can a new players’ association help level the court?
content: On Halloween night 2019, the Canadian tennis player Vasek Pospisil faced Chris O’Connell, an Australian, in a third-round match at the Charlottesville Men’s Pro Challenger in Virginia. The event was part of the A.T.P. Challenger Tour, a rung below the main circuit in men’s tennis. The match had a minor-league vibe: There were maybe a dozen spectators, and one of them was Pospisil’s coach. The total purse for the weeklong tournament was just $54,000, not uncommon for Challenger-level events. The winner would get $7,200.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Barnard, Katie Glueck and Jeffery C. Mays
title: What to Expect as Early Ranked-Choice Results Are Released in New York
description: Absentee ballots won’t be included, but data to be released Tuesday could signal the way vote totals will shift as the field is officially winnowed.
content: Update: Eric Adams’s lead narrowed significantly after the first unofficial ranked-choice tally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: ‘Ready to take further action’: Biden officially notifies Congress of his airstrikes on Iran-allied militias.
description: The notification, in compliance with the War Powers Act, came as Mr. Biden drew criticism over the strikes from some in his own party.
content: President Biden officially notified Congress on Tuesday about his justification for recent American airstrikes against Iranian-backed militias in Syria and Iraq, declaring that he acted to “defend the safety of our personnel” and to “deter the Islamic Republic of Iran” and its proxies from further attacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Radtke
title: Letter of Recommendation: Gossip
description: As it says in Proverbs: “The words of a whisperer are like delicious morsels.”
content: In middle school I learned how to solve for the hypotenuse and identify properties of an atom, but the most enduring skill I picked up was how to gossip. Eighth grade in particular was consumed by chatter and rumors — my classmates and I had spent nine years together, witnessing one another’s staggered entrances into puberty. As a class of 26, we had perhaps more access to one another than is advisable at such a vulnerable age.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka, Saif Hasnat, Yu Young Jin, Mujib Mashal and Aina J. Khan
title: Concern over the Delta variant triggers lockdowns in Asian and Pacific countries.
description: Australia, Bangladesh and Malaysia are among the nations scrambling to contain outbreaks as sluggish vaccination drives leave populations vulnerable.
content: Countries across the Asia-Pacific region are scrambling to slow the spread of the more infectious Delta variant, reimposing restrictions and stay-at-home orders in a jarring reminder — for societies that had just begun to reopen — that the pandemic is far from over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Imbler
title: The Sound of One Walrus Clapping
description: Spoiler: It’s very loud.
content: Starting in the late 2000s, Colleen Reichmuth and Ole Larsen made a number of visits to Six Flags Discovery Kingdom in Vallejo, Calif., to hear a walrus make some noise. The male Pacific walrus, named Sivuqaq, was approaching sexual maturity, which meant he might soon spout the signature din that male walruses make in breeding season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin, Apoorva Mandavilli and Shawn Hubler
title: Masks Again? Delta Variant’s Spread Prompts Reconsideration of Precautions.
description: Los Angeles County and the W.H.O. warned that even immunized people should wear masks indoors. Some scientists agreed, but urged a localized approach.
content: Throughout the pandemic, masks have ranked among the most contentious public health measures in the United States, symbolizing a bitter partisan divide over the role of government and individual liberties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Jill Biden will be on the cover of Vogue.
description: The magazine suspended the tradition of featuring first ladies during the Trump administration.
content: The White House appears to be back in Vogue’s good graces.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Vixen,’ by Francine Prose: An Excerpt
description: An excerpt from “The Vixen,” by Francine Prose
content: In the winter of 1954, I was assigned to edit a novel, The Vixen, the Patriot, and the Fanatic, a steamy bodice-ripper based on the Rosenberg case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Why California Banned State-Funded Travel to Florida and Elsewhere
description: Tuesday: Officials are expanding a ban on taxpayer-funded travel to places that have enacted anti-L.G.B.T.Q. legislation.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: United Airlines Plans a Record Fleet Expansion as Travel Rebounds
description: The carrier is ordering 270 single-aisle planes from Boeing and Airbus, signaling confidence that the pandemic is receding and travelers will spend on premium service.
content: United Airlines announced on Tuesday that it would place the largest order for airplanes in its history and create about 25,000 jobs a year after a pandemic devastated its business, betting on a domestic travel boom and demand for more expensive, premium seats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: No. 3 House Democrat Steps Into Ohio Race to Head Off a Sanders Acolyte
description: The decision by Representative James Clyburn to oppose an outspoken ally of Senator Bernie Sanders in a special election in Cleveland highlights the generational and ideological gulf in the Democratic Party.
content: WASHINGTON — Early last year, as Bernie Sanders was surging through the first Democratic presidential primary races, Representative James E. Clyburn of South Carolina, a kingmaker in his state, stepped in to endorse Joseph R. Biden Jr. before the primary there, helping vault the former vice president to the nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Fox News agrees to a $1 million penalty after workplace culture investigation.
description: The 24-hour cable channel reached the settlement after a formal review of sexual harassment complaints by the New York City Commission on Human Rights.
content: Fox News agreed to pay a $1 million penalty under a settlement reached last week with the New York City Commission on Human Rights. The case stemmed from a cascade of sexual misconduct allegations that shook the network several years ago and led to the exits of Roger Ailes, its co-founder, and the anchor Bill O’Reilly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scaachi Koul
title: When Adult Daughters Realize Their Mother Is Being Abused
description: In Hanna Halperin’s debut novel, “Something Wild,” a family contends with its troubled past and brutal present.
content: SOMETHING WILDBy Hanna Halperin
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon and Lynsey Chutel
title: South African Court Orders Arrest of Ex-President Jacob Zuma for Contempt
description: Mr. Zuma, whose tenure was tainted by financial scandals, was a comrade of Nelson Mandela and a dominant figure for decades in the governing African National Congress party.
content: JOHANNESBURG — South Africa’s highest court on Tuesday ordered the imprisonment of Jacob Zuma, the country’s former president, for 15 months on contempt charges, after he defied an order to appear before a corruption inquiry examining the breathtaking financial scandals that tainted his tenure as the country’s leader from 2009 to 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Backs Pipeline in Case on New Jersey Land Seizures
description: By a 5-to-4 vote, the court said the federal government could delegate its power to condemn state property to a private company.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court cleared the way on Tuesday for a pipeline to transport natural gas from Pennsylvania to New Jersey, ruling that PennEast Pipeline Company, the project’s developer, may exercise the federal government’s power of eminent domain to condemn land owned by New Jersey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arthur Lubow
title: Now You See the Art. Now You Don’t.
description: In their first collaboration, the High Line and the Shed invite the public to a sculpture hunt, in augmented reality. Do you see the ladybug? The floating ice cube?
content: On a torrid afternoon in June, Emma Enderby, chief curator of the Shed, and Cecilia Alemani, director and chief curator of High Line Art, walked side by side between their respective bailiwicks on the West Side of Manhattan, plotting the configuration of their first collaborative exhibition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Why Do We Work So Damn Much?
description: Hunter-gatherers worked 15-hour weeks. Why don’t we?
content: Historically speaking, we live in an age of extraordinary abundance. We have long since passed the income thresholds when past economists believed our needs would be more than met and we’d be working 15-hour weeks, puzzling over how to spend our free time. And yet, few of us feel able to exult in leisure, and even many of today’s rich toil as if the truest reward for work is more work. Our culture of work would be profoundly puzzling to those who came before us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pat Garofalo
title: How Amazon, Google and Other Companies Exploit NDAs
description: Asking elected officials to keep silent  is bad for democracy.
content: In March, when the City Council of Fort Wayne, Ind., voted 7 to 2 to approve $16 million in tax breaks for a corporation to open a distribution center in the city, it was something of a shot in the dark: Four of the Council members — including two who voted in favor of the deal — didn’t know which corporation they were considering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Marc Jacobs Has the First Major Live Fashion Show in New York
description: Another sign the return has begun.
content: Bruce Springsteen is not the only beloved cultural figure who has declared New York City open again for business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: New York Mayor’s Race in Chaos After Elections Board Counts 135,000 Test Ballots
description: The extraordinary sequence of events threw the closely watched Democratic primary contest into a new period of uncertainty and seeded further confusion about the outcome.
content: The New York City mayor’s race plunged into chaos on Tuesday night when the city Board of Elections released a new tally of votes in the Democratic mayoral primary, and then removed the tabulations from its website after citing a “discrepancy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Crashes involving Tesla Autopilot and other driver-assistance systems get new scrutiny.
description: Federal safety regulators told automakers to provide more information about accidents involving cars and trucks with automation technology.
content: A federal safety agency told automakers on Tuesday to begin reporting and tracking crashes involving cars and trucks that use advanced driver-assistance technology such as Tesla’s Autopilot and General Motors’ Super Cruise, a sign that regulators are taking the safety implications of such systems more seriously.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Old John’s Diner Updates an Upper West Side Classic
description: A NoMad spot from a Le Coucou alumnus, an intimate new space for Junoon, and more restaurant news.
content: What was Old John’s Luncheonette for decades, a neighborhood anchor that attracted marquee names from ABC Studios nearby, has reopened after a pandemic pause. It was first at Broadway and 66th Street, then a block away at 67th Street. And now it has a slight change in its name.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Marks
title: An uneasy silence from Ethiopia and Eritrea over what’s next.
description: With a bigger humanitarian disaster looming, diplomats are trying to keep a Tigrayan victory from becoming a wider war.
content: As Tigrayan forces celebrated returned control over their regional capital, Mekelle, there was mostly silence from senior Ethiopian officials back in the nation’s capital, Addis Ababa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Poletto
title: Sleeping in the Outdoors
description: With pandemic anxiety lingering even as the world opens up, some are finding comfort — and a good night’s sleep — in tents, pavilions and sleeping porches.
content: When the interior designer Greg Baudoin and his partner, Greg Campbell, a floral designer, purchased and renovated a lake house in Snow Lake Shores, Miss., they expected to use it as a weekend retreat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Freddie Mercury and Virginie Despentes: What ‘We Are Lady Parts’ Is Made Of
description: Nida Manzoor, the creator, writer and director of the series, shares what things inspired her to make a show about Muslim women in a punk band.
content: There have been many stories about being young, obsessed with music and starting a band, and the series “We Are Lady Parts” does nail the fundamentals: the joys and the arguments, the feuds and the romantic entanglements, the mortifying gigs and the uplifting concerts.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews James Suzman
description: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with James Suzman. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with James Suzman. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Louisa Lim
title: Hong Kong’s Last Gasp
description: The cherished freedoms that distinguished the city from mainland China are being demolished.
content: It took just six days to shut down Apple Daily.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Privacy Watchdog Board’s Secret Report on N.S.A. System Fell Short, Member Says
description: The Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board spent more than six years scrutinizing the surveillance-related system, called XKeyscore. Its report is classified.
content: WASHINGTON — A member of a civil liberties watchdog board that investigates the nation’s security programs criticized on Tuesday a major — but still secret — report by his organization about a National Security Agency surveillance-related system, portraying the effort as shoddy and a missed opportunity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Berkman
title: Minor League Parks, Stripped of America’s Pastime, Await New Fates
description: A reorganization by Major League Baseball has left 40 municipalities seeking long-term solutions for their abandoned stadiums.
content: The artwork of elementary school students decorates the office windows behind home plate at Richmond County Bank Ballpark in Staten Island. One encourages residents not to litter. Another drawing, of the stadium’s infamous Staten Island pizza rat mascot, reads: “Better Days Are Coming!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: Why You Still Might Want to Have a Home Covid Test on Hand
description: At-home rapid Covid-19 tests can offer unique benefits for weddings, parties, travel or for households with children or at-risk adults.
content: Got the sniffles? Worried about that night out in a crowded dance club? Or maybe you just want to visit grandma but are concerned about her risk, even though you’re vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Economists grapple with how much racism is to blame for a wide pay gap.
description: After a year in which demands for racial justice acquired new resonance, some experts are pushing back against a strongly held tenet of economics: that differences in wages largely reflect differences in skill. Economists should stop looking for a reason other than racism, they say, to account for why African Americans are falling further behind in the economy.
content: After a year in which demands for racial justice acquired new resonance, some experts are pushing back against a strongly held tenet of economics: that differences in wages largely reflect differences in skill. Economists should stop looking for a reason other than racism, they say, to account for why African Americans are falling further behind in the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Funny or Racist? A Food Bit on James Corden’s Late Show Draws Ire.
description: For years, the late-night TV host has dared celebrities to eat choice foods, but an online petition is calling for it to end.
content: For years, the late-night television host James Corden has played a food-based truth or dare with celebrities called “Spill Your Guts or Fill Your Guts.” Participants choose to either answer personal questions or take a bite of a food deemed disgusting to eat, like ghost pepper hot sauce, a sardine smoothie or dried caterpillars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Eric Schmitt
title: Security in Afghanistan Is Decaying, U.S. General Says as Forces Leave
description: “Civil war is certainly a path that can be visualized,” said Gen. Austin S. Miller, commander of the U.S.-led forces. “That should be a concern for the world.”
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — The commander of the U.S.-led mission in Afghanistan warned on Tuesday that the country could be on a path to chaotic civil war as American and other international troops prepare to leave in the coming weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cathi Hanauer
title: A Humbled Millennial Goes Home to New Jersey to Find Herself
description: In Beck Dorey-Stein’s first novel, “Rock the Boat,” a 34-year-old woman ends up on the Jersey Shore, right where she started.
content: ROCK THE BOATBy Beck Dorey-Stein
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: John Langley, a Creator of the TV Series ‘Cops,’ Dies at 78
description: “You can be entertained by it, you can be disgusted,” he said of the popular reality show that embedded film crews with police officers in the streets for 31 years.
content: John Langley, a creator of “Cops,” the stark-looking reality television crime series that followed police officers on drug busts, domestic disputes and high-speed chases for more than 30 years, died on Saturday in Baja, Mexico. He was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Kim Jong-un Lost Weight. No One Knows How or Why.
description: North Koreans say they were “heartbroken” when they saw Kim Jong-un looking “emaciated.” The regime has turned the weight loss into a propaganda victory.
content: SEOUL — All they had was TV footage — and a wristwatch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: As Biden woos Wisconsin, Trump picks a fight with local Republicans.
description: President Biden returns to Wisconsin on Tuesday. His predecessor has never really left.
content: President Biden returns to Wisconsin on Tuesday. His predecessor has never really left.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly and Peter Eavis
title: Lower Rents? Check. Speakeasy? Check. How Office Landlords Are Enticing Tenants.
description: As New York City stirs to life, landlords are trying to hold on to their tenants by redesigning spaces to accommodate social distancing and Zoom calls — but also socializing.
content: Even as life returns to many New York City neighborhoods, its big commercial districts are awash with empty office space. Most workers haven’t yet returned — and it’s unclear if they all will. That uncertainty is terrifying the city’s biggest office landlords, and many of them are going to great lengths to retain and attract tenants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe and Steve Lohr
title: Congress Faces Renewed Pressure to ‘Modernize Our Antitrust Laws’
description: After a federal judge threw out state and federal competition cases against Facebook, calls grew for lawmakers to quickly change century-old monopoly laws.
content: WASHINGTON — When the nation’s antitrust laws were created more than a century ago, they were aimed at taking on industries such as Big Oil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Elizabeth Martínez, Voice of the Chicana Movement, Dies at 95
description: Through her writings, she inspired, provoked, educated, strategized, organized and built cross-racial and cross-ethnic alliances, all in pursuit of social justice.
content: Elizabeth Martínez, a feminist, writer and community activist who helped organize the Chicana movement, which sought to empower people, like her, who were of Mexican descent and born in the United States, died on Tuesday in San Francisco. She was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: Meet the U.S. Women’s Gymnastics Team
description: Here are the American gymnasts you’re likely to see on the awards podium.
content: Here are the American gymnasts you’re likely to see on the awards podium.

description: For timid children, more social situations can pose particular challenges.

title: How Weird Is the Heat in Portland, Seattle and Vancouver? Off the Charts.
description: The heat smothering the Pacific Northwest has little precedent in four decades of record-keeping.

title: Biden Touts ‘Bipartisan Breakthrough’ on Infrastructure
description: President Biden used an appearance in Wisconsin to pitch the bipartisan agreement announced last week, calling it the largest federal infrastructure investment since the Interstate highway system.
content: President Biden used an appearance in Wisconsin to pitch the bipartisan agreement announced last week, calling it the largest federal infrastructure investment since the Interstate highway system.

author: By Ben Proudfoot
title: The Queen of Basketball
description: Lusia Harris led her team to three national championships, scored the first basket in women’s Olympic history and was officially drafted by the New Orleans Jazz in 1977.

author: By Declan Walsh and Christina Kelso
title: Mass Celebrations as Fighters From Tigray Reclaim City
description: Residents cheered on the streets of Mekelle, Ethiopia, after rebels retook control of the regional capital from government forces. Ethiopia’s government had occupied the region for months, with reports of atrocities against civilians, including sexual violence and arbitrary killings.
content: Residents cheered on the streets of Mekelle, Ethiopia, after rebels retook control of the regional capital from government forces. Ethiopia’s government had occupied the region for months, with reports of atrocities against civilians, including sexual violence and arbitrary killings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Haigney
title: Caveh Zahedi Has So Many Stories to Tell
description: After plunging into a TV series, a filmmaker low on funds but loaded with rich personal narratives pours them into micro-podcasts.
content: Caveh Zahedi was in a closet in a Brooklyn Heights apartment on a recent Sunday, trying to figure out how to end the story he was telling. He had been talking about a college class he’d taken with the filmmaker Michael Roemer. When Roemer saw Zahedi’s class project, a film titled “Sex and Violence,” he said, “‘I think you need serious help; you really need to be in therapy,’” Zahedi recalled. He cried on the spot when he heard those words.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: June 29, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, June 29, 2021.
content: An article on Saturday about Manhattan landmarks that honor Chinese Americans and Native Americans misidentified the city department that maintains the Kimlau War Memorial and the similarly named plaza. It is the parks department, not the police department.
source.name: The New York Times
